title: Old Mortality, Complete
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: John Balfour of Kinloch, or Burley, for he is designated both ways in thehistories and proclamations of that melancholy period, was a gentleman ofsome fortune, and of good family, in the county of Fife, and had been asoldier from his youth upwards.

title: Old Mortality, Complete
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: On Hackston refusing the command, it was by universal suffrage     conferred on John Balfour of Kinloch, called Burley, who was     Hackston's brother-in-law.

title: Traditions of Edinburgh.
author: Chambers, Robert
snippet: Sir David Kinloch and a Mr Justice were their best male associates ; and the chief female pei'former, after Mrs Macrae herself, was Mrs Carruthers of Dormont, a daughter of the celebrated artist Paul Sandby.

title: Traditions of Edinburgh.
author: Chambers, Robert
snippet: She married David Smith, Esq. of Methven, one of the Lords of Session ; Miss Jardine of Edinburgh, who married Mr Home Drummond of Blairdrummond — their daughter, if I mistake not, is now the Duchess of Athole ; Miss Kinloch  of Gilmerton, who married Sir Foster Cunliffe of Acton, Bart.

title: A selection from the correspondence of the late Thomas Chalmers /
author: Chalmers, Thomas
snippet: N.B. — I kept this letter open until I received Mr. Morison'sanswer, which I hereby inclose for the purpose ofyour makingany use of it with Mr. Kinloch that may seem right.

title: A selection from the correspondence of the late Thomas Chalmers /
author: Chalmers, Thomas
snippet: I guess a letter to be the raost impressiveform of application to Mr. Morison, and have accordingly written him to write Mr. Kinloch.

title: A selection from the correspondence of the late Thomas Chalmers /
author: Chalmers, Thomas
snippet: That you may understand it, it is only necessary for me to say, thatthe occasion of it must have been an application on the part of my sather for Dr. Chalmers's influence on his behalf, with the view of obtaining the presentation to the parish of Bendochy, then vacant, and whichhe ultimately succeeded in doing, mainly through the exertions of thelate George Kinloch, Esq., of Kinlooh, who was a particular friend ofmy father's.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The list contained one or twonames of distinction; as Buchanan of Arnpryor,the chief of his name ; MacDonald of Kinloch-Moidart, one of the first who received the Princeon his landing; MacDonald of Teindreich, whobegan the war by attacking Captain Scott's detachment when marching to Fort Augustus, and JohnMacNaughton, a person of little note, unless in solar as he was said, but it is believed erroneously,to have been the individual by whose hand ColonelGardiner fell at Preston.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: He had been a free liver inhis youth, but latterly had adopted strong and enthusiastic views of religion, which led him into theextreme opinions entertained by the fiercest of theWhig party.2 John Balfour of Kinloch, calledBurley, the brother-in-law of Hackston, is described,by a covenanting author, as a little man, of sternaspect, and squint-eyed; none of the most religious,3but very willing to engage in any battles or quarrelswhich his comrades found it necessary to sustain.
